paragraphs.text: Thanks for pleasant read:) Nice idea about content indexation!

Simple findElementById calls should give you all you need. I may be wrong thought.

e2594f44d815.title: As a fellow redditor, I don’t see how losing access to your account really impedes your redditing…

paragraphs.text: As a fellow redditor, I don’t see how losing access to your account really impedes your redditing LOL . I just uninstalled the reddit app for android & got a chrome extension that blocks the front page with a message of your choice.

1b566b6e15a4.title: Ah, you’re absolutely right Karl, that would be a great optimization to improve the average case!

paragraphs.text: Ah, you’re absolutely right Karl, that would be a great optimization to improve the average case!
paragraphs.name: 93f5

paragraphs.text: The other optimization I didn’t attempt here would be to make all of the requests for each character concurrently (i.e., making A requests in parallel). This would roughly double the number of requests though, and would be more likely to trigger rate-limiting.

26ad92edc89.title: And the moral of the story is… develop enough self-control so you don’t have to lock yourself out…

This was all so preventable.

f554424196e6.title: Intuitively, you should be able to solve this with some windowing.

paragraphs.text: Intuitively, you should be able to solve this with some windowing. I.e., if the search bar only allowed a search window of size K, just build up the first window of size K and then slowly slide it all the way forward (deleting the first letter and working out the last one), then slide it all the way backward.
paragraphs.name: 2a59

virtuals.subtitle: The only case where this would break down is if there are repeated substrings of size ≥ K. In a pathological case I believe this may lead…

content.subtitle: The only case where this would break down is if there are repeated substrings of size ≥ K. In a pathological case I believe this may lead…

75a94ff8af1f.title: Haseeb Qureshi I have a couple quick questions for you: (1) Which back-end language did you learn?

paragraphs.text: Haseeb Qureshi I have a couple quick questions for you: (1) Which back-end language did you learn? (2) Which resources did you use to learn it? (and if you have the time — 3) Why this language?
paragraphs.name: 88c4

paragraphs.text: That'’ fricking brilliant! Awesome hacking.
paragraphs.name: cda1

paragraphs.text: Hey,
paragraphs.name: 3d26

paragraphs.text: Great article!
paragraphs.name: bb69

paragraphs.text: I was wondering if you were to find all the letters/numbers in the password on the first round and then use them + ‘pasword’ letters to check forward and backward. Would it be faster?
paragraphs.name: 405b

paragraphs.text: Brilliant. What would happen if the letter-me-later site had a limitation on the size of the search query that was smaller than the password length? Would this technique still work with some tinkering?
